Works

Orion

For this collaborative three.js experiment, my good friend Thibaut started things off by writing this rad shader, that I then took, polished, and turned into a generative application.

It is built upon my text-seeded PRNG utility (see next project), allowing to save and share random outcomes simply by bookmarking the URL.

I really loved working on the generative side, so I'll probably do more of those in the future.

Vesuna

Generative applications are a lot of fun. However, when there is a wide range of possible outcomes, it can become tedious to save, restore and share them.

To solve this issue, I wrote this tiny text-based random seed utility, built around Johannes Baagøe's Alea PRNG. It generates pseudorandom number sequences based on words, making it very easy to save/load precise results via hashtags.

Disintegrator

Brainstorming for an upcoming project, I envisioned elements exploding. So I made this lab to try my hand at that.

After several attempts, I ended up using tesselation, custom buffer attributes, and a mix of basic random + simplex noise. It also uses a few duplicated/layered geometries, in order to counteract their inherent hollowness.

It is still raw and optimizable, but the visual result is pretty close to what I wanted.

Textformer

I love randomness, and I love experimenting with type. This resulted in this small javascript utility, that allows to make easy text animations based on random character changes.

I wanted it to be usable on its own, so I ended up writing and including a barebones tweening system. However, it also works great with engines such as gsap or anime.js.

About

Hello!

My name is Pierre "Keda" Audéoud. I'm a 38-years-old creative coder, working freelance and living in Paris, France.

My work is mostly made in vanilla javascript & three.js, with a strong focus on motion, randomness and interactivity. I also really like GLSL and sci-fi aesthetics.

I am currently looking to join a creative studio.
